Award.AwardTitle: Hadronic and Nuclear Structure and Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goals of this project are to advance the theoretical understanding of hadrons and light nuclei using effective theories that are rigorously consistent with the fundamental theory of the strong interactions, Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). In single hadrons, the project will continue the development of improved chiral effective theoretical methods in baryons by applying in the low-energy regime a framework known as the 1/N expansion of QCD. By studying excited baryons in this framework, this research relevant for the analysis of current experimental results on baryon resonances from various facilities, including the Jefferson Laboratory, and it can also be applied to connect with recent results of Lattice QCD calculations of the excited baryon spectrum. In few-body physics, the research is focused on applying the combined chiral effective theory and 1/N expansion to study the nucleon-nucleon potential, with possible extensions to few-body currents.

This project will focus on the fundamental properties of QCD as manifested in the context of hadronic and nuclear systems. An important mission of this research concerns the education and training of undergraduate and graduate students at Hampton University, one of the historically black institutions. The PI's long-standing involvement with the theoretical and experimental programs at the Jefferson Laboratory provides students with unique learning and research opportunities at one of the premier experimental facilities in the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
General description of the project:
The project titled "Hadronic and Nuclear Structure and Dynamics" aims at the theoretical study of hadronic and nuclear physics using methods which are rooted in fundamental aspects of the theory of the strong interactions, Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). Those methods broadly known as effective theories are in this project focused on the low and intermediate regimes of hadronic physics, and more specifically in hadrons known as baryons (such as the proton and neutron). The methods allow for organizing and understanding observables in a rigorous way, despite the extraordinarily complex dynamics that determine the properties of hadrons from their fundamental constituents quarks and gluons.

Objectives:
The objectives of the project are:
1) Develop tools based on effective theories to study baryons. The effective theories aim at full consistency with fundamental symmetries of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD), namely flavor, chiral and their breaking by quark masses and with the expansion  associated with the number of colors Nc of QCD which adds important constraints on effective theories. 
2) Apply effective theories to excited baryons (resonances) which is an area of baryon physics of high experimental and phenomenological interest, to low energy baryons in the realm of chiral dynamics.
3) Study both experimental and lattice QCD results.
4) The project included studies of non-perturbative QCD effects using the approach of holographic QCD, in particular pure gauge QCD where the possibility of a non-vanishing gluon condensate was explored.

Main results and achievements:
The most important outcomes of the project were the following ones:
1) One work performed a complete study of excited baryons, namely the first spin-flavor multiplet of negative parity. Such a study involved the masses and the strong and electromagnetic transitions. This study based on the 1/Nc expansion further illuminates the properties of these excited baryons and serve as an example for  similar works still to be carried out in other cases.
2) The masses of excited baryons, including strange baryons, obtained in lattice QCD calculations by the Jefferson Lab lattice group were analyzed using the 1/Nc expansion. This work serves as a test of numerous mass relations implied by the 1/Nc expansion, and also allowed to determine the quark mass dependencies of the different terms in the mass formulas. This is the first work of its kind.
3) The combination of the 1/Nc expansion with chiral perturbation theory for baryons (BChPT x 1/Nc), first developed in a previous NSF award, was applied to lattice QCD calculations performed for the low lying baryon masses at different values of Nc. This is the first work of its kind and opens a new possibility of testing the 1/Nc expansion in QCD.
4) A major effort in implementing BChPT x 1/Nc for three flavors was carried out during the award, and part of the project has been completed under the present award a new NSF award. New results were obtained for effects of symmetry breaking due to the mass of the strange quark on the charges associated with the vector currents, in particular the currents corresponding to the weak (beta) decays of hyperons. In addition the axial vector currents and the baryon masses and their dependencies on the quark masses were studied. The works show the high importance of including in the effective theory the constraints that are required by the 1/Nc expansion of QCD. This is currently a novel line of work with possibilities for applications to all aspects of low energy baryon physics.


Broader impacts: adds to the development of effective theories in general. Opens new inquires on how to formulate effective theories that are consistent with all expansions of QCD, namely low energy/chiral and 1/Nc and show that our building of effective theories of QCD is still an area in progress expected in particular to give  important new insights  applications to both phenomenology and lattice QCD results for baryons. In education, the project supported one PhD student, who graduated from Hampton University in the Fall 2017. The project also supported undergraduate research by one Junior physics major at Hampton University.
